title: Vase, "Design #R497", ca. 1940
provenance: 2012, Damon Crain gift to Cooper-Hewitt; July 16, 2003, Damon Crain purchased from Ontario, Canada, collection
dimensions: H x diam.: 25.4 x 15.9 cm (10 in. x 6 1.4 in.)
description: sea green, the everted body with cinched waist  applied with a spiral coil above a weighted base
justification:
Selected for the Metropolitan Museum of Art's 1950 exhibition "Twentieth Century Glass, American and European", this vase&nbsp;was one of fifty works in the exhibition, and Blenko was&nbsp;one of the few American companies, appearing with equal status as European counterparts such as&nbsp;Emil Galle,&nbsp; Orrefors, and Louis&nbsp;Comfort Tiffany. &nbsp;Technically listed in a circa 1940 catalogue on the"Heavy Swedish type" page&nbsp;without designer, the vase, the only one of this series with an applied coil, was almost certainly&nbsp;the design of Carl Ebert Erickson, the foreman and de facto&nbsp;chief designer&nbsp;of Blenko&nbsp;into World War II.&nbsp; Erickson had worked at the Pairpoint Factory prior to coming to Blenko and came from a line of Swedish glassmakers: both his father and grandfather were master blowers at the Reimyre factory in Sweden.&nbsp; Erickson left Blenko to found his own company, Erickson Glassworks in Ohio. His departure was the inspiration for Blenko, soon after the war, to hire&nbsp;its first&nbsp;full-time, in-house designer, Winthrop Anderson.
